tgt_text.2326: Neither number, therefore, nor rank, nor conjunction, nor any other of the remaining parts of speech, I think, does the letter signify, but that it is an address to the god, or an invocation, complete in itself, that together with the utte­ rance thereof puts the speaker in mind of the power of the deity.
tgt_text.2327: For the god addresses each one of us here, when ap­ proaching him, as if with a salutation, in the words, ‘ Know thyself,' which is neither more nor less than ‘ Hail,' whilst we, in requital to the god, say, ‘ Thou art,’1 as though paying to him the true, undying, and sole property of him­ self, the predicate of existence.
tgt_text.2330: For we ourselves have in reality no part in existence ;
tgt_text.2331: for all mortal nature being in a state between birth and dissolution, presents no more than an illusion, and a semblance, shapeless and unstable of itself, and if you will closely apply your thought, out of the wish to seize hold of the idea, just as the too strong grasping at water when it is pressed together and condensed, loses it, for it slips through your fingers, in the same way Reason, in pursuing after the appearances, so extremely clear as they look, of each one of the conditions of life as they pass along, misses its aim;
tgt_text.2332: impinging on the one side against its coming into existence, on the other, against its going out;
tgt_text.2333: without ever laying hold upon it as a permanent thing, or as being in reality a power.
tgt_text.2334: It is not possible, according to Heraclitus, to step into the same river twice;
tgt_text.2335: neither is it to lay hold of mortal life twice, in the same condition;
tgt_text.2336: but by reason of the suddenness and speed of its mutation, it disperses and again brings together, or rather, neither again nor afterwards, but at one and the same time it subsists and it comes to an end;
tgt_text.2337: it ap­ preaches and it departs, wherefore it never ripens that of it which is born into actual being, by reason that Birth doth never cease nor stand still, but transforms;
tgt_text.2338: and out of the seed makes the embryo, then the child, then the youth, young man, full-grown man, elderly man, old man -obliterating the former growths and ages by those grow­ ing up over them.
tgt_text.2339: But we ridiculously fear one death, although we have already died, and are still dying, so many;
tgt_text.2340: for not only, as Heraclitus says, ' When fire dies is the birth of air, and when air dies is the birth of water,' but still more plainly may you see it from ourselves:
tgt_text.2341: the full-grown man perishes when the old man is produced, the youth had before perished into the full-grown man, and the child into the youth, and the infant into the child;
tgt_text.2342: and the ‘ yesterday' has died into the ‘ to-day,' and the ' to-day' is dying into the ‘ to-morrow,' and no one re­ mains, nor is one, but we grow up many around one appear­ ance and common model, whilst matter revolves around and slips away.
tgt_text.2343: Else how is it, if we remain the same, that we take pleasure in some things now, in different things before;
tgt_text.2344: we love contrary objects, we admire and find fault with them, we use others words, feel other pas­ sions ;
tgt_text.2345: not having either appearance, figure, nor disposi­ tion the same as before ?
tgt_text.2346: To be in different states, with­ out a change, is not a possible thing, and he that is changed is not the same person;
tgt_text.2347: but if he is not the same, he does not exist . . . this very thing (the change) he changes1—growing one different person out of another;
tgt_text.2348: but Sense, through ignorance of reality, falsely pronounces that what appears existsXIX.
tgt_text.2351: The answer is, the eternal, unborn, undecaying, to which no length of time brings about a change:
tgt_text.2352: for Time is a thing movable and making move, making its appearance conjointly with matter ;
tgt_text.2353: leaking and not holding water, as it were, a vessel full of decay and growth;
tgt_text.2354: for is not the predicate ‘ After' and ‘ Before,' ‘ Future,' and ‘ Past,' of itself an acknow­ ledgment of non-existence ?
tgt_text.2355: For to say that what has not yet been, or what has ceased from being, is in being, how silly and absurd !

tgt_text.2357: For it (Time) is diverted, like a ray of light, into the Future and the Past, necessarily separated, when we attempt to see it.
tgt_text.2358: And if the Nature that is measured is in the same condition as that which measures it, nothing is either stable or exists ing, but all things are either being born or perishing, accord­ ing to their distribution with respect to time.

tgt_text.2362: But the god is, we must declare;
tgt_text.2363: and is with reference to no time, but with reference to the eternal, the immovable, timeless, and indeclinable ;
tgt_text.2364: that which there is nothing before nor after, nor more, nor past, nor older nor younger, but He being One with the one ‘ Now,' hath filled up the ‘ Ever;
tgt_text.2365: ’1 and that which really is, alone is with reference to Him;
